While the U.S. Small Business Administration (SBA) doesnâ€™t have a standalone commercial vehicle loan program, most SBA loans can be used to finance a variety of business equipment, including commercial vehicles.

SBA loans have competitive interest rates and offer favorable repayment terms. But thereâ€™s a catch: SBA lenders typically require borrowers to have good credit and an established business with a proven track record of success.

Whatâ€™s an SBA commercial vehicle loan?

An SBA commercial vehicle loan is a business loan used to buy, repair or upgrade a new or used vehicle for business purposes. You get cash upfront to finance the purchase or repairs, and then repay your lender slowly over time, with interest.

SBA loans are offered by participating lenders and are partially guaranteed by the SBA. They are meant to serve small-business owners who are having trouble securing more traditional financing. Individual lenders have the final say on who qualifies.

Which SBA loans can be used for business vehicles?

Many SBA loans can be used to finance a commercial vehicle. Hereâ€™s a snapshot of the options:

SBA 504 loan

Heavy equipment vehicles that can't travel freely on roadways without a special permit, such as backhoe loaders and cranes.

Which vehicles can an SBA loan be used for?

The SBA doesnâ€™t spell out which vehicles lenders are allowed to finance. Instead, it sets general guidelines for how SBA loans should be used when buying or repairing business equipment.

This means that whether youâ€™re trying to buy your first work van to shuttle tools between job sites or youâ€™re repairing a fleet of excavators, an SBA loan may help foot the bill, so long as itâ€™s used for business purposes and you qualify.

Examples of commercial vehicles include:

  • Cars.

  • SUVs.

  • Vans.

  • Light trucks.

  • Buses.

  • Box trucks.

  • Heavy equipment vehicles, such as bulldozers and cement mixers.

  • Other specialty vehicles.

Pros and cons of SBA commercial vehicle loans

Here are the main upsides and drawbacks to getting an SBA loan to finance a business vehicle.

Pros

Competitive interest rates.

Can be used to fund multiple vehicles at once.

Cons

Can be hard to qualify for.

Can take months to receive funding.

Lots of paperwork required.

Down payment and collateral may be required.

How to get an SBA commercial vehicle loan

Make sure you meet the basic requirements

While individual lenders and the type of SBA loan you apply for will dictate whether you get approved, there are some basic requirements youâ€™ll likely have to meet, such as:

  • Having a for-profit U.S. business that fits within the SBAâ€™s size standards

  • Demonstrating your need for financing by having exhausted non-SBA loan options first.Â 

  • A personal credit score of approximately 650 or higher.

  • At least two years of being in business.

Find a lender

There are many lenders that offer SBA loans. Your job is to find one that matches your needs while offering a competitive interest rate and repayment terms.

To start, check out NerdWalletâ€™s list of best SBA lenders, which feature some of the most active SBA lenders. You can also use the SBAâ€™s lender matching tool to get matched with potential lenders.

Alternatives to SBA commercial vehicle loans

  • Conventional bank or credit union loans. Like SBA loans, these tend to have competitive interest rates and favorable repayment terms. They can be even harder to qualify for than SBA loans, though they tend to have slightly faster approval times.
